The patient's course has been complicated by respiratory failure, secretions, agitation, and reintubation. The patient's current condition includes bronchoscopy with likely left upper lobe infiltrating mass, central venous line (CVL) placement, supraventricular tachycardia (SVT), and restart of amiodarone.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, blood pressure of 102/49 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is sedated and has limited movement.

The patient's physical examination reveals edema in the lower extremities, muscle wasting, warm skin on the right lower extremity, and cool skin on the left lower extremity. Neurological assessment is not available.

Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased platelet count, elevated creatinine levels, elevated troponin-T, and abnormal liver function tests. Other lab values are within normal range or not significantly abnormal.

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and CAD who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure. He has an MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia and is suspected to have a new left lung mass, likely malignancy. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with permissive hypercapnia, intubated, and sedated. He is being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia and sepsis. The patient also has atrial ectopy, including atrial fibrillation and atrial tachycardia, and is on amiodarone. His HCT dropped from 30 to 24.9 range, possibly due to stress gastritis or blood loss, and he received 1 unit of packed red blood cells. His creatinine is still elevated at 1.6 range, possibly due to hypotension and acute tubular necrosis.

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has exacerbated hypercarbic respiratory failure due to pneumonia and sepsis. It is important to continue A/C ventilation and keep tidal volumes low to avoid further lung injury.
2. Decreased compliance of the left lung: The patient has evidence of decreased compliance on the left lung, which may require adjustments in ventilation settings and possibly intubation for a repeat bronchoscopy with biopsy.
3. Hypotension/septic shock: The patient has hypotension and septic shock secondary to

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy, and coronary artery disease (s/p CABG). He was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and bacteremia.

The patient's current conditions include hypotension, delirium/confusion, acute pain, atrial flutter, cellulitis, acute renal failure, other cardiomyopathy, and septic shock. 

Medical Interventions:
- Continue Zosyn for 10 days and IV Vanco for 6 weeks.
- Continue neosynephrine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) >65.
- Trend lactate and monitor cardiac output (CvO2) every 8 hours.
- Switch back to levophed if acutely worsened.
- Follow urine output, aiming for 30 cc/hr.
- Follow up on all pending microbiology/culture data.

HCT Drop:
- Drop in hematocrit (HCT) from 30 to 24.9 range observed.
- Positive guaiac today and questionable abdominal discomfort.
- Repeat HCT stat.
- Trend HCTs every 8 hours.
- Check repeat stool guaiacs and abdominal exams.
- Hold subcutaneous heparin for now.
- Given cardiac history, administer 1 Unit packed red blood

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient has a history of CHF, CAD, COPD, NSCLC, and possibly recurrent malignancy.
- The patient experienced hypercapnic respiratory failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and hypotension.
- The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a low tidal volume strategy and is receiving vasopressors for hemodynamic support.
- The patient's laboratory results show elevated WBC count, low platelet count, and elevated glucose levels.
- The patient's ABG results indicate respiratory acidosis with hypercapnia.
- The patient's vital signs include tachycardia, low blood pressure, and increased respiratory rate.
- The patient's physical examination reveals hyperresonant percussion notes on the chest and trace bilateral lower extremity edema.
- The patient's neurologic status is not assessed due to sedation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): Due to the patient's prolonged mechanical ventilation and immobility, there is an increased risk of developing VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)/pulmonary embolism (PE): Immobility and decreased venous return can increase the risk of DVT formation, which may lead to a potentially life-threatening PE.
3. Nosocomial infection: Prolonged hospitalization and invasive procedures can increase the risk of nosocomial infections, such as central line-associated bloodstream infections

   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia new found to have new L lobe mass
   likely malignancy.
   # Hypercarbic respiratory failure:
   Exacerbated in setting of PNA with sepsis. Also has baseline  h/o COPD
   on oxygen at home. Also now found to have left mass. Has evidence of
   decreased compliance yesterday
 improved today after diuresis with
   good RSBI.
   - Hold on extubation today given poor TVs on PSV of 15/5
   - Continue diuresis to goal 1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs
 day#13 of steroids today, will
   continue for 2 more days
   # L sided lung mass, concern for cancer recurrence
   - Will need intubation after plavix washout for repeat bronch with
   biopsy
   # Hypotension: Suspect septic etiology.   Being treated for HAP. Still
   pressor dependent.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #4) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - Continue neosynephrine  to MAP>65, wean as tolerated
   .- Follow up all pending micro/ culture data
   .

   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .

   # [**Last Name (un) **] : Cr still elevated at 1.6 range. Likely elevated In setting of
   hypotension and probable element of recent  ATN.
   - Repeat PM lytes

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, ischemic cardiomyopathy, ventricular tachycardia (VT) with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) and pacemaker (PM) placement, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, and a past lung cancer that underwent right upper lobe (RUL) lobectomy. The patient was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, leading to respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. 

The patient has been receiving various treatments including intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI), anticoagulants, antibiotics, vasopressor support with phenylephrine, sedation with propofol, and amiodarone for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib with RVR). The patient's condition has shown improvements in respiratory compliance and oxygenation.

However, there are several potential medical complications to consider:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline COPD and recent MRSA pneumonia have exacerbated his respiratory failure, resulting in hypercarbia. This is a concern for ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and should be closely monitored.
2. Left-sided lung mass: A new left lobe mass has been identified, which raises concerns

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery, ischemic cardiomyopathy, ventricular tachycardia (with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator and pacemaker), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (on home oxygen), and prior lung cancer (right upper lobe lobectomy). He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia and sepsis, which led to respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current condition includes:

1. Positive guaiac and hemoglobin concentration drop: The patient has received one unit of packed red blood cells. The cause of the hemoglobin drop is suspected to be stress gastritis. It is important to trend hemoglobin levels, perform repeat stool guaiacs, and check abdominal exams. The patient should be kept with a hemoglobin concentration greater than 25.

2. Hypotension and septic shock: The patient is being treated for healthcare-associated pneumonia. Blood pressure has been stable on neoephrine (0.1 mcg/kg/min). Vasodilatory shock is likely, and the plan is to continue Zosyn for 10 days and vancomycin for 6 weeks. Neoephrine will be weaned as tolerated, aiming for a mean arterial pressure greater than 65.

3. Decreased pulmonary compliance and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS): The patient is on ARDS

He is also receiving multiple infusions of medications, including phenylephrine, propofol, amiodarone, and pantoprazole.

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient likely has hypercarbic and hypoxemic respiratory failure, possibly due to lung injury. Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy, and coronary artery disease (s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. He has a new left lung mass likely malignancy, awaiting Plavix washout for biopsy of mass in OR.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Multifactorial - baseline COPD, less lung volume on right and new left lung mass, volume overload with decreased compliance. Also has difficulty with secretions.
   - Hold on extubation due to inability to tolerate P/S. [Month (only) 51] have repeat bronch with biopsy as early as tomorrow (Tu) by IP.
   - Continue diuresis by Lasix gtt to goal 1L negative today.
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs. Day#14 of predisone 20mg today, plan to switch to 10mg PO prednisone tomorrow [5-6].

2. L sided lung mass, concern for cancer recurrence
   - Plan for repeat bronch/biopsy tomorrow/Wed by IP.
   - Hold TF after midnight in case procedure tomorrow.

3. Hypotension: Likely component of hypotension from propofol. Also s/p septic physiology. Being treated for HAP. Still pressor dependent.
   - Continue Z

He is currently on mechanical ventilation with a respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute and an FiO2 of 35%. His vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 124/53 mmHg, heart rate of 80 bpm, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's renal function is impaired with an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) of 27.6 mL/min. The patient's overall condition remains stable with no recent complications.

   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia new found to have new L lobe mass
   likely malignancy.
   # Hypercarbic respiratory failure:
   Exacerbated in setting of PNA with sepsis. Also has baseline  h/o COPD
   on oxygen at home. Also now found to have left mass. Has evidence of
   decreased compliance yesterday
 improved today after diuresis with
   good RSBI.
   - Hold on extubation today given poor TVs on PSV of 15/5
   - Continue diuresis to goal 1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs
 day#13 of steroids today, will
   continue for 2 more days
   # L sided lung mass, concern for cancer recurrence
   - Will need intubation after plavix washout for repeat bronch with
   biopsy
   # Hypotension: Suspect septic etiology.   Being treated for HAP. Still
   pressor dependent.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #4) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - Continue neosynephrine  to MAP>65, wean as tolerated
   .- Follow up all pending micro/ culture data
   .
   # Atach/afib : Plan to continue on Amiodarone. [**Month (only) 51**] switch to quinidine
   as outpt.
   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   #HCT Drop :  Drop in HCT from 30 to 24.9 range now. Positive guaiac
   today and questionable abdominal discomfort. Received 1 unit pRBCs
   yesterday. [**Month (only) 51**] be stress gastritis
   -will trend HCTs daily, keep >25
   # [**Last Name (un) **] : Cr still elevated at 1.6 range. Likely elevated In setting of
   hypotension and probable element of recent  ATN.
   - Repeat PM lytes
   - Follow urine output (keep UOP>50cc/hr)
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   --opting to hold Plavix for upcoming IP bronch/biopsy
   - continue  ASA 81mg

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy, and coronary artery disease (s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. He has a new left lung mass, likely malignancy. The patient's current medical complications include hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, left-sided lung mass (concern for cancer recurrence), Hct drop, and elevated creatinine.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 37.3 C (99.2 F)
- Heart rate: 80 bpm
- Blood pressure: 124/53 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 17 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 100% on endotracheal tube with FiO2 35%
- Central venous pressure: 7 mmHg

The patient's lab results show:
- White blood cell count: 10.0 - 10.6 K/uL
- Hematocrit: 28.5 - 29.1%
- Platelet count: 145 - 178 K/uL
- Creatinine: 1.6 - 1.7 mg/dL
- Blood glucose: 154 - 162 mg/dL
- Other labs: Elevated troponin-T, lactic acid, LDH, and abnormal electrolyte levels

The patient's current plan includes:
- Continue diuresis to goal 1L negative
- Continue steroid taper and MDIs
- Intubation after Plavix washout for repeat bronch with biopsy
- Continue Zosyn x 10 days total and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
- Continue neosynephrine to MAP >65, wean as tolerated
- Follow up all pending micro/culture data
- Continue Amiodarone and switch to quinidine as outpatient
- Trend HCTs daily, keep >25
- Repeat PM lytes and follow urine output

Please note that this summary is based on the provided progress note, and additional information may be required to fully assess the patient's condition.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a medical history of COPD, CAD, and lung cancer. He was admitted with MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia and is now suspected to have recurrent lung cancer. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. His vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 119/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient has been receiving various medications, including antibiotics for MRSA pneumonia and suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), anticoagulants, and cardiovascular support.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient remains intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to the inability to control secretions and poor respiratory reserve caused by underlying pneumonia, right upper lobe resection, and left upper lobe involvement by an obstructing lesion. There is a need to establish goals of care prior to extubation.

2. Hypotension: The patient is pressor-dependent and requires neosynephrine to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg. 

3. Tachycardia: The patient has been prescribed amiodarone (400 mg) to manage tachycardia.

4. Anemia: The patient's hematocrit (hct) was trending down but is now stable.

   Assessment and Plan:
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia found to have new L lobe mass on
   recent bronchoscopy concerning for recurrent cancer & now awaiting IP
   repeat bronch/biopsy this morning
   .
   # Hypercarbic respiratory failure:  Very poor reserve due to baseline
   COPD. He also had prior RUL lobectomy in
96 for lung cancer. On serial
   imaging he has less lung volume on R and now a newer L lung mass and
   respiratory failure with need for intubation despite multiple broad
   antibiotics.  He also has ongoing volume overload issue with decreased
   compliance overall making his ventilation in ICU challenging. Excessive
   secretions continue. Plan for IP bronch/biopsy today.
   - IP procedure with bronch/biopsy today
   - Holding on extubation due to inability to tolerate P/S
   - Continue diuresis by lasix gtt to goal -1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs
 day#15 of predisone 20mg today,
   plan to switch to 10mg today
   # L sided lung mass:  major concern for cancer recurrence
   - follow-up results of repeat bronch/biopsy today by IP
   - Holding TF until after procedure done
   - d/w IP when safe to place back on Plavix ( if at all) after biopsy
   # Hypotension: Still having transient episodes of low BPs to 80/50s.
   Likely from propofol effects / amiodarone therapy and his overall
   septic physiology.   Being treated for HAP. Responds well to pressor
   medications.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #6) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - Continue neosynephrine  to MAP>65, wean as tolerated
   - f/up micro/ culture data, none positive so far
   - took 1.5 L off last night pre-bronch today so may need to ease up on
   lasix drip later today as long as MAPs appropriate
   .
   # Atach/afib : Plan to continue on Amiodarone.  [**Month (only) 51**] switch to quinidine
   as outpt, but per EP will likely just plan to switch to PO amiodarone
   as he has responded well to this therapy. Overnight still had several
   brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased
   diuresis.
   - continue PO amiodarone with re-bolus PRN
   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   #HCT Drop :  Improved now from 27-28 up to 30 range. [**Month (only) 51**] be stress
   gastritis. Hct has been stable, has not required transfusions since
   [**5-2**].
   -will trend HCTs [**Hospital1 7**], keep >25
   - active T/S
   # [**Last Name (un) **] : Cr still elevated at 1.8 range today . Likely elevated In
   setting of ongoing hypotension issues and probable element of recent
   ATN.
   - Repeat PM lytes
   - Follow urine output (keep UOP>50cc/hr) which has been good
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   --have been holding Plavix for past week for IP bronch/biopsy today
   - continue  ASA 81mg

He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and vasopressor support. Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer (right upper lobe lobectomy). He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and vasopressors. He is currently awaiting an interventional procedure for concern of recurrent lung cancer. The patient's medical allergies include no known drug allergies. He is receiving various medications including furosemide, phenylephrine, propofol, heparin sodium, pantoprazole, and others. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 122/49 to 149/58 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 97%, and a paced heart rhythm. The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 370 mL, respiratory rate set at 14 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 35%, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 24 cmH2O, and plateau pressure of 21 cmH2O.

   Assessment and Plan:
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia new found to have new L lobe mass
   likely malignancy awaiting plavix washout for biopsy of mass in OR.
   # Hypercarbic respiratory failure:  Multifactorial: baseline COPD, less
   lung volume on R and new L lung mass, volume overload with decreased
   compliance. Also has difficulty with secretions.
   - Hold on extubation due to inability to tolerate P/S. [**Month (only) 51**] have repeat
   bronch with biopsy as early as tomorrow (Tu) by IP
   - Continue diuresis by lasix gtt to goal 1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs
 day#14 of predisone 20mg today,
   plan to switch to 10mg PO prednisone tomorrow [**5-6**]
   # L sided lung mass, concern for cancer recurrence
   - Plan for repeat bronch/biopsy tomorrow/Wed by IP
   - Hold TF after midnight in case procedure tomorrow
   # Hypotension: Likely component of hypotension from propofol. Also s/p
   septic physiology.   Being treated for HAP. Still pressor dependent.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #5) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - Continue neosynephrine  to MAP>65, wean as tolerated
   .- Follow up all pending micro/ culture data, none positive so far
   .
   # Atach/afib : Plan to continue on Amiodarone. [**Month (only) 51**] switch to quinidine
   as outpt.
   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   #HCT Drop :  [**Month (only) 51**] be stress gastritis. Hct has been stable, has not
   required transfusions since [**5-2**]
   -will trend HCTs [**Hospital1 7**], keep >25
   - active T/S
   # [**Last Name (un) **] : Cr still elevated at 1.7 range. Likely elevated In setting of
   hypotension and probable element of recent  ATN.
   - Repeat PM lytes
   - Follow urine output (keep UOP>50cc/hr) which has been good
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   --opting to hold Plavix for upcoming IP bronch/biopsy (tomorrow will be
   5 days off plavix
   - continue  ASA 81mg

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer with right upper lobe (RUL) lobectomy. He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and vasopressors. The patient is currently awaiting an interventional procedure for a left-sided lung mass, which is suspected to be recurrent lung cancer.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has difficulty with secretions, decreased lung volume due to the new left lung mass, and baseline COPD, leading to hypercarbic respiratory failure. Measures such as diuresis and bronchoscopic interventions may be necessary.
2. Volume overload: The patient has a negative fluid balance, indicating volume overload. Diuretics (Lasix) are being used to manage this condition.
3. Hypotension: The patient is pressor-dependent and hypotensive, possibly due to septic physiology and propofol infusion. Vasopressors like neosynephrine are being used to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65 mmHg.
4. Atach/afib: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and amiodarone is being used for rate control. Quin

Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) on home oxygen, and a previous right upper lobe lobectomy for lung cancer. He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and pressors. The patient is currently awaiting an interventional procedure (IP) bronchoscopic biopsy to investigate a new left lung mass, which is concerning for recurrent lung cancer.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: Due to the patient's baseline COPD and previous right upper lobe lobectomy, he has poor reserve and is at risk for hypercarbic respiratory failure. The ongoing volume overload and decreased lung compliance make ventilation challenging.

2. L-sided lung mass: The presence of a new left lung mass is concerning for cancer recurrence. The results of the repeat bronchoscopic biopsy will determine if this is indeed recurrent cancer.

3. Hypotension: The patient experiences transient episodes of low blood pressure, likely due to the effects of propofol and amiodarone therapy, as well as his overall septic physiology. He responds well to pressor medications and is being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer. He was admitted with MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. His hospital course has been notable for a new left upper lobe (LUL) mass concerning for carcinoma. He underwent bronchoscopy and biopsy this morning, which was well-tolerated with no bleeding. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure, likely multifactorial related to MRSA pneumonia, recurrent lung cancer, and volume overload. He also has hypotension, atrial fibrillation/supraventricular tachycardia (AF/SVT), a drop in hematocrit (Hct), and coronary artery disease (CAD).

Potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is already present and may continue if not properly managed.
2. LUL mass: The biopsy results of the LUL mass need to be monitored, and further treatment decisions will depend on the findings.
3. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension is likely due to sedation and the effects of the bronchoscopy procedure. Monitoring and appropriate management of blood pressure support are necessary.
4. AF/SVT: The patient has been stable overall but has experienced transient tachycardic events with low blood pressure. Continuous monitoring and management with amiodarone are recommended.
5.

The patient underwent a biopsy with IP and is currently receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics. The patient's vital signs are stable with a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 85/44 mmHg to 128/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient's weight has decreased from 87.2 kg at admission to 85.5 kg currently.

The patient is receiving respiratory support through an endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation mode, set tidal volume (Vt) of 370 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 35%. The patient's respiratory status is assessed as stable with adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

The patient's laboratory results show normal white blood cell (WBC) count, hemoglobin (Hct), platelet count (Plt), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine (Cr), total carbon dioxide (TCO2), glucose, and electrolyte levels. However, the patient has elevated lactate levels at 36.2%, indicating possible tissue hypoperfusion.

The patient is diagnosed with hypotension, delirium, pain control issues, atrial flutter, cellulitis, acute renal failure, other cardiomyopathy, septic shock, acute respiratory failure, and code status full code.

ICU Care:

The patient is receiving enteral nutrition through NovaSource Renal (Full) at a rate of 45 mL/hour. Glycemic control measures are in place, and the patient has multiple lines, including a PICC line, arterial line, and multi-lumen line. Prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcers, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) are also being implemented.

Potential Medical Complications:

Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is consistently below the normal range, which can lead to inadequate tissue perfusion and organ dysfunction.

3. Pain Control Issues: The patient is experiencing acute and chronic pain,

   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia found to have new L lobe mass on

   .
   # Hypercarbic respiratory failure:  Baseline COPD and s/p RUL lobectomy
   in
96 for lung cancer. On serial imaging he has less lung volume on R
   and now with a newer left sided lung mass which was biopsied with IP on
   [**5-6**].  Despite multiple antibiotics for PNA patient
s respiratory
   failure has required prolonged intubation.  Poor lung compliance,
   excessive secretions, and ongoing volume overload issues continue to
   challenge his ventilation in ICU. RSBI in low 100s this morning.
   - f/up IP bronch/biopsy  results
   - f/up ABG on current P/S settings
    -Continue diuresis by lasix gtt to goal -1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#16 today, down
   to 10mg daily )
   #HAP : Recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia. No recent fevers or
   leukocytosis.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #7 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - CIS
   .
   # L sided lung mass:  major concern for cancer recurrence
   - follow-up results of repeat bronch/biopsy today by IP
   - place back on Plavix therapy today
   # Hypotension:  Better overnight.  He had some paralytics for IP
   procedure yesterday and was more heavily diuresed pre-procedure which
   likely  created his lower CVPs yesterday and low BPs.  Poor cardiac
   function, propofol effects / amiodarone therapy continue to add to his
   low BPs. Continues on current neosynephrine pressor  with goal MAPs >
   65.
   -
   - Continue neosynephrine  to MAP>65, wean as tolerated
   - f/up micro/ culture data
   - PM CvO2 and lactate to ensure no ischemia w/ pressor
   - monitor I/Os, try to maintain UOP > 30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs
   ( goal >[**5-29**]) & MAPs ( >65) ; may need to restart lasix drip later today
   if becomes too positive / overloaded
   .

   as outpt, but per EP will likely just plan to switch to PO amiodarone
   as he has responded well to this therapy. Overnight still had several
   brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased

   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia found to have new L lobe mass on
   recent bronchoscopy concerning for recurrent cancer & now awaiting IP
   repeat bronch/biopsy this morning
   .

   COPD. He also had prior RUL lobectomy in
96 for lung cancer. On serial
   imaging he has less lung volume on R and now a newer L lung mass and
   respiratory failure with need for intubation despite multiple broad
   antibiotics.  He also has ongoing volume overload issue with decreased
   compliance overall making his ventilation in ICU challenging. Excessive
   secretions continue. Plan for IP bronch/biopsy today.
   - IP procedure with bronch/biopsy today
   - Holding on extubation due to inability to tolerate P/S
   - Continue diuresis by lasix gtt to goal -1L negative today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs
 day#15 today, plan to switch to

will be safe to place back on Plavix  about 24hrs after

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) post-coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and previous lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy. He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and pressors. The patient is now awaiting an intraoperative repeat bronchoscopy and biopsy due to concern for recurrent lung cancer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has poor reserve due to baseline COPD and a prior right upper lobe lobectomy. He also has decreased lung volume on the right side and a new left lung mass. These factors make his ventilation in the ICU challenging, and excessive secretions continue.

2. L-sided lung mass: The presence of a new left lung mass is a major concern for cancer recurrence. Follow-up results of the repeat bronchoscopy and biopsy are pending.

3. Hypotension: The patient continues to have transient episodes of low blood pressure (80/50s). This is likely due to propofol effects/amiodarone therapy and overall septic physiology. The patient is being treated for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) and responds well to pressor medications.

4. Atach/afib: The patient has episodes of atrial fibrillation.

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and lung cancer who was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis. He required intubation and pressors and is currently awaiting an interventional bronchoscopy and biopsy for concern of recurrent lung cancer. The patient has undergone a biopsy with intraoperative propagation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent lung cancer: The patient's history of lung cancer and the concern for recurrent lung cancer may pose a potential medical complication.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's acute respiratory failure, not associated with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), could potentially worsen if there are complications during the bronchoscopy or if his underlying lung condition deteriorates.
3. Sepsis: Despite initial treatment, the patient remains at risk for sepsis due to his MRSA infection and compromised immune system.
4. Hypotension: The patient's ongoing hypotension requires careful monitoring and management to ensure adequate organ perfusion.
5. Delirium/confusion: The patient's delirium/confusion may be attributed to sepsis, hypotension, or other factors, which need to be addressed to improve his mental status.
6. Pain control: The patient's acute and chronic pain need to be managed

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), coronary artery disease (CAD), and previous right upper lobe (RUL) lobectomy for lung cancer. He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and vasopressors. The patient is currently awaiting an intraoperative (IP) bronchoscopy and biopsy due to concern for recurrent lung cancer. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline COPD and previous RUL lobectomy may contribute to this condition. The decreased lung volume on the right side and the presence of a new left-sided lung mass further complicate ventilation in the ICU.
2. HAP (Healthcare-associated pneumonia): The patient has a recent history of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. Ongoing treatment with piperacillin/tazobactam and vancomycin is necessary.
3. L-sided lung mass: The presence of a new left-sided lung mass raises concern for cancer recurrence. Follow-up results of the repeat bronchoscopic biopsy are pending.
4. Hypotension: The patient's low blood pressure may be attributed to poor cardiac function, propofol effects, amiodarone therapy, and recent diuresis. Phenylephrine pressor is being used to maintain mean arterial pressure (MAP) above 65

   Assessment and Plan:
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of new L lobe mass.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Multifactorial etiology. Baseline COPD and s/p
   RUL lobectomy in
96 for lung cancer. On serial imaging he has less
   lung volume on R and now with a newer left sided lung mass which was
   biopsied with IP on [**5-6**].  Despite multiple antibiotics for PNA
   patient
s respiratory failure has required prolonged intubation.  Poor
   lung compliance, excessive secretions, and ongoing volume overload
   issues continue to challenge his ventilation in ICU which we have been
   working to improve with diuresis, secretion control. RSBI in low 100s
   this morning but had tachycardia in SBT.
   - hold on extubation before clarify goals
   - f/up IP bronch/biopsy  results
   -Run his I/Os even today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#17 today, down
   to 10mg daily)
   - Talk to family regarding trach/PEG vs DNR/DNI status with trial of
   extubation
   #HAP : Recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia. No recent fevers or
   leukocytosis.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #7 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - CIS
   .
   # L sided lung mass:  major concern for cancer recurrence
   - follow-up results of repeat bronch/biopsy today by IP
   # Hypotension:  Better overnight.  He had some paralytics for IP
   procedure yesterday and was more heavily diuresed pre-procedure which
   likely  created his lower CVPs yesterday and low BPs.  Poor cardiac
   function, propofol effects / amiodarone therapy continue to add to his
   low BPs. Were able to wean down off pressors this AM. [**Month (only) 51**] be [**2-25**]
   propofol hypotension so may still need low dose with re-sedation
   - Try to stay off pressors if possible, can do fluid boluses prn
   - f/up micro/ culture data
   - monitor I/Os with goal even/slightly negative today, try to maintain
   UOP > 30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs ( goal >7) & MAPs ( >65)
   .
   # Atach/afib : Plan to continue on Amiodarone.  [**Month (only) 51**] switch to quinidine
   as outpt, but per EP will likely just plan to switch to PO amiodarone
   as he has responded well to this therapy. Overnight still had several
   brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased
   diuresis.
   - continue PO amiodarone with re-bolus PRN, especially when we trial
   extubation
   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   #HCT Drop :  Stable now at 28 -30 range. [**Month (only) 51**] be stress gastritis. Has
   not required transfusions since [**5-2**].
   -will trend HCTs [**Hospital1 7**], keep >25 given CAD history
   - active T/S
   # [**Last Name (un) **] : Cr still elevated at 1.6  range today ( has been 1.6-1.8 past
   few days)  . Likely elevated In setting of ongoing hypotension issues
   and probable element of recent  ATN earlier in ICU course.
   - Repeat PM lytes
   - Follow urine output (keep UOP>40cc/hr) which has been good
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   - restarted on plavix yesterday, continue plavix
   - continue  ASA 81mg
   # Anxiety
 Patient with delirium/anxiety when not intubated last time.
   Psych was following prior for this
   - check EKG to see whether can use haldol prn (ie: 1mg PO Q8hr prn)

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), COPD, and lung cancer (prior right upper lobe lobectomy) admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and sepsis. He required intubation and vasopressors and is currently awaiting an interventional bronchoscopic biopsy for concern of recurrent lung cancer. The patient's atrial fibrillation has improved overnight with no notable supraventricular tachycardia flare-ups. He underwent a biopsy with interventional procedures and was weaned off neosynephrine at 9 AM this morning. The patient's respiratory support includes CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator with a tidal volume set at 370 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 35%. He is currently on amiodarone and propofol infusions. Other medications include piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), vancomycin, and phenylephrine. The patient's vital signs are as follows: temperature 36.8°C, heart rate 81 beats per minute, blood pressure 85/44 mmHg, respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, coronary artery bypass grafting, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and previous right upper lobe lobectomy for lung cancer. He was admitted with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia and sepsis, requiring intubation and vasopressors. He underwent an intraoperative bronchoscopy and biopsy for concern of recurrent lung cancer.

Current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 81 beats per minute, blood pressure of 85/44 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on CPAP/PSV ventilation. The patient is currently receiving phenylephrine and propofol infusions.

The patient's recent laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and normal platelet count. Electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for a slightly elevated potassium level. Blood glucose levels are also elevated.

The patient's physical examination reveals reactive pupils with decreased extraocular movement, good air movement in the anterior chest, and bilateral rhonchi in the lungs. Cardiac examination shows regular rate and rhythm without murmurs or rubs. Abdominal examination is unremarkable.

Assessment and plan:
- Hypotension not in shock
- Delirium/confusion
- Pain control

The patient is a 79-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD. He presented with MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia and was found to have a right upper lobe mass. The patient is currently in the ICU and is receiving various treatments including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and cardiac medications. He is also receiving nutritional support and has been placed on a ventilator due to respiratory failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is currently improving, but there is still an element of volume overload. It is important to continue monitoring his oxygenation and ventilation parameters, and adjust ventilator settings as necessary. If the patient fails a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT), tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) may be considered.
2. Left Upper Lobe Mass: Further evaluation is needed for the pulmonary mass, including pathology results and staging CT scan. This will help determine the appropriate course of treatment.
3. MRSA Pneumonia/Bacteremia: The patient is being treated with vancomycin for MRSA infection. It is important to monitor for any signs of treatment failure or drug resistance. Cultures should be repeated to ensure clearance of the infection.
4. Coronary Artery Disease: Plavix should be held, and aspirin and beta-blocker therapy should be continued.

   Assessment and Plan
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of new L lobe mass.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Extubated yesterday and has been stable off
   vent so far, still with high O2 requirement but weaning down. Will help
   his respiratory status by diuresis as CXR showing more fluid in lungs
   s/p extubation
   - run his I/Os negative today ( neg 1-2 L )
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#18 today, down
   to 10mg daily)
   - Talk to family regarding pathology results of squamous cell ca and
   goals of care/next steps
   # Delirium: Patient with delirium/anxiety when not sedated.
   - continue Haldol 3mg qpm and 1-2 mg PRN q 8 hrs during daytime
   - check EKG / QT  today
   -consider using depakote
   #HAP : Recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia. No recent fevers or
   leukocytosis.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #8 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - CIS
   - change Vanco to 1g q 24 hours
   .
   # L sided lung mass:  IP biopsy results now confirmed as squamous cell
   lung cancer.
   - consider family meeting with goals of care changes
   - staging with CT studies once more stable
   -heme/onc consult today  & possibly RAD/Onc involvement
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   - restarted on beta blocker and titrate up for now
   - restarted on plavix yesterday, continue plavix
   - continue  ASA 81mg
   - start ACE today or tomorrow as tolerated for afterload reduction
   #CHF:  recent EF 35%. Fluid overloaded on exam
   - consider starting ACE today or tomorrow, BP allowing
   -will diuresed to goal negative 1-2L today
   - keep MAPs >65
   # Hypotension:  Off pressors. Improved off propofol sedation
   - f/up micro/ culture data
   - monitor I/Os with goal even/slightly negative today, try to maintain
   UOP > 30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs ( goal >7) & MAPs ( >65)
   .
   # Atach/afib: Plan to continue on PO Amiodarone.  Overnight still had
   several brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased
   diuresis.
   -continue lopressor 5mg q 4hrs for control
   - continue PO amiodarone
   -cont telemetry
   -follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   #HCT Drop :  Decreased to 26.[**5-26**] be stress gastritis. Has not
   required transfusions since [**5-2**].
   -will trend HCTs [**Hospital1 7**], keep >25 given CAD history
   - active T/S
   - guaiac stools
   # CKI : Cr still elevated at 1.6  range today ( has been 1.6-1.8 past
   few days)  . Likely elevated In setting of ongoing hypotension issues
   and probable element of recent  ATN earlier in ICU course. Given
   longevity this is likely CRF with new baseline vs. [**Last Name (un) **].
   - Repeat PM lytes
   - Follow urine output (keep UOP>40cc/hr) which has been good

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer, and CAD (s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of a new left lobe mass.

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient was extubated yesterday and has been stable off vent so far, still with high O2 requirement but weaning down.
- The patient had a brief desaturation episode last night and required a face mask for oxygen supplementation.
- The patient experienced an episode of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) after extubation, for which IVF bolus and amiodarone were administered. The patient still remains tachycardic and has been started on lopressor.
- The patient has had some fluctuations in blood pressure and requires close monitoring of I/Os with goal even/slightly negative today, trying to maintain UOP >30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs (goal >7) & MAPs (>65).
- The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still requires high flow oxygen.
- The patient's delirium/anxiety when not sedated is being managed with Haldol.
- The patient's recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia are being treated with Zosyn x 10 days total (day #8 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks

- He has been extubated but required reintubation due to ongoing volume overload issues and poor lung compliance.

- There is a concern for cancer recurrence on the left side.

- He has been experiencing episodes of atrial fibrillation (afib) and is being treated with amiodarone.
- The patient has experienced a drop in hemoglobin concentration, which may be due to stress gastritis.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe (RUL) lobectomy, and coronary artery disease (CAD) status post coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and bacteremia following a biopsy of a new left-sided lung mass.

The patient has been intubated and on invasive ventilation, but has recently been extubated. He experienced supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) after extubation and received intravenous fluids (IVF) bolus and amiodarone. Despite this, he remained tachycardic, so lopressor was started at a dose of 5 mg IV every 6 hours. The patient also had a brief episode of desaturation in the high 80s with a respiratory rate in the 30s, for which a face mask was applied, and he recovered after suctioning.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (99°F), heart rate of 81 bpm, blood pressure of 104/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 100% on high-flow nasal cannula, and central venous pressure (CVP) of 11 mmH

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, and CAD (s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of a new L lobe mass. He has been intubated and mechanically ventilated due to multifactorial respiratory failure, including poor lung compliance, excessive secretions, and ongoing volume overload. The patient's delirium/anxiety has been managed with Haldol, and he continues to receive multiple antibiotics for MRSA PNA. A biopsy of the left lung mass confirmed squamous cell lung cancer. The patient's hypotension has improved, and he is no longer on pressors. He is currently extubated and receiving oxygen via a high-flow nasal cannula. The patient's atach/afib is being managed with PO amiodarone, and he will continue to have close monitoring of his heart rhythm.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's baseline COPD and previous right upper lobe lobectomy may contribute to his poor lung compliance and ongoing respiratory failure. Close monitoring of his respiratory status is essential to prevent further deterioration.
2. Delirium/Anxiety: The patient exhibits delirium/anxiety when not sedated, which requires ongoing management with Haldol. Regular assessment of his mental status is important to identify

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted to the hospital with complaints of shortness of breath and chest pain. On admission, his vital signs were stable, but he required immediate intubation due to respiratory distress. Since then, he has experienced several medical complications.

The patient's condition has been complicated by delirium, hypotension, pain control issues, atrial flutter, cellulitis, acute renal failure, other cardiomyopathy, septic shock, and acute respiratory failure. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) results indicate a pH of 7.42, PaCO2 of 54 mmHg, PaO2 of 240 mmHg, HCO3- of 31 mEq/L, BE of -9 mEq/L, and O2 saturation of 100%.

The patient's laboratory values show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 144 K/uL, elevated blood glucose level of 161 mg/dL, elevated creatinine level of 1.8 mg/dL, and elevated lactate level of 1.0 mmol/L. The patient's platelet count is within normal range.

The patient's physical examination reveals that he is unresponsive and unable to assess his peripheral vascular status, skin condition, neurologic function, and tone. The patient has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 11 mmHg and requires ongoing respiratory support with high flow nebulization and CPAP/PSV ventilation mode.

The patient's current medications include amiodarone, lopressor, lorazepam, and heparin sodium. He has received multiple doses of antibiotics, including piperacillin/tazobactam, vancomycin, and piperacillin.

Based on the information provided, the potential medical complications that can arise include worsening renal function, respiratory distress, sepsis, cardiac arrhythmias, and delirium. It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, ABG results, laboratory values, and response to treatment in order to manage these complications effectively.

   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of new L lobe mass.
   .

   Baseline COPD and s/p RUL lobectomy in
96 for lung cancer. On serial
   imaging he has less lung volume on R and now with a newer left sided
   lung mass which was biopsied with IP on [**5-6**].  Despite multiple
   antibiotics for PNA patient
s respiratory failure has required
   prolonged intubation.  Poor lung compliance, excessive secretions, and
   ongoing volume overload issues continue to challenge his ventilation in
   ICU which we have been working to improve with diuresis, secretion
   control. RSBI in low 100s this morning but had tachycardia in SBT.
   - f/up IP bronch/biopsy  results
   -Run his I/Os even today
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#18 today, down
   to 10mg daily)
   - Talk to family regarding trach/PEG vs DNR/DNI status with trial of
   extubation
   # Delirium
 Patient with delirium/anxiety when not sedated.
   - check EKG to see whether can use haldol prn per psych recs. Other
   recs from before include using depakote
   #HAP : Recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia. No recent fevers or
   leukocytosis.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #8 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - CIS
   .
   # L sided lung mass:  major concern for cancer recurrence
   - follow-up rushed results of pathology
   # Hypotension:  Off pressors. Improved off propofol sedation
   - f/up micro/ culture data
   - monitor I/Os with goal even/slightly negative today, try to maintain
   UOP > 30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs ( goal >7) & MAPs ( >65)
   .
   # Atach/afib : Plan to continue on Amiodarone.  [**Month (only) 51**] switch to quinidine
   as outpt, but per EP will likely just plan to switch to PO amiodarone
   as he has responded well to this therapy. Overnight still had several
   brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased
   diuresis.
   - continue PO amiodarone with re-bolus PRN, especially when we trial

   -cont telemetry

   .

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer surgery (lobectomy), and coronary artery disease (CAD) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure due to MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia following a biopsy of a new left lung mass. The patient has been intubated and required prolonged mechanical ventilation due to poor lung compliance, excessive secretions, and volume overload issues. He was recently extubated but experienced tachycardia and desaturation, requiring the use of non-invasive ventilation support. The patient also had delirium and anxiety when not sedated. He has been diagnosed with recent MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia and is currently being treated with antibiotics. There is a major concern for cancer recurrence in the left-sided lung mass. The patient's hypotension has improved off pressors, and he is being monitored closely for fluid balance and electrolyte management. He is also being treated for atrial fibrillation with amiodarone. The patient's hematocrit level has decreased to 26%, likely due to stress gastritis, and he is being closely monitored for kidney function and urine output. His cardiac status, including a history of CAD and CABG, is stable at this time. The patient's family has been informed about the tracheostomy/PEG tube versus DNR/DNI status with a trial of extubation.

1. Respir

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and right upper lobe resection for SCLCA. He has been admitted with MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia, and now presents with a new lesion in the left upper lobe. The patient was extubated yesterday and tolerated well, but experienced brief tachycardia and hypoxemia overnight. He also became agitated and received haloperidol. The patient has multiple medical conditions including respiratory failure, recurrent lung cancer, atrial tachycardia, CAD with CHF, delirium, hypotension, and CKD. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient may experience further respiratory compromise due to his pre-existing conditions (COPD and CHF) and the presence of a new lung lesion. Close monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation is necessary.

2. Recurrent Lung Cancer: The new lesion in the left upper lobe suggests recurrent lung cancer. This could lead to worsening respiratory symptoms and potentially further respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.

3. Atrial Tachycardia and Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial tachycardia and is currently in atrial fibrillation. These arrhythmias can lead to hemodynamic instability and complications such as heart failure.

4. Coronary Artery Disease with Congestive Heart Failure: The patient's history of CAD

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU. The patient has a history of no known drug allergies. The patient received Piperacillin and Vancomycin antibiotics on [**2183-5-8**] at 08:31 PM and 09:00 PM, respectively. The patient is currently on various medications including Metoprolol and Heparin Sodium for prophylaxis. The patient's review of systems remains unchanged from admission except as noted below.

Vital signs show a temperature of 36.8 C (98.2 F) with a current temperature of 36.4 C (97.6 F). The patient's heart rate is 84 bpm with a range of 80-106 bpm. Blood pressure readings are 126/52 mmHg and 102/44 mmHg with a range of 76-131/57-80 mmHg. The patient's respiratory rate is 21 breaths per minute with a range of 20-39 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation is at 98% on high flow nebulizer. The patient's height is 65 inches and weighs 85.5 kg, which is slightly less than the admission weight of 87.2 kg.

Hemodynamic monitoring reveals a CVP of -1 mmHg with a range of -9 to 47 mmHg. Fluid balance shows an input of 1,265 mL and an output of 2,365 mL, resulting in a negative balance of -1,100 mL. Blood products totaling 1,160 mL and urine output of 2,015 mL were also recorded. The patient is receiving various infusions including Metoprolol and Heparin Sodium. The patient is on respiratory support with high flow nebulizer and oxygen saturation of 98%.

Physical examination findings include absent peripheral pulses, unassessed skin, and unassessed neurologic status. Lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, increased glucose levels, and abnormal electrolyte levels. Radiology images were also obtained.

Assessment and plan include hypotension, delirium/confusion, pain control, atrial flutter, cellulitis, acute renal failure, other cardiomyopathy, septic shock, acute respiratory failure, and other conditions. The patient is receiving ICU care including nutrition, glycemic control, and various lines. Prophylactic measures for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP are being implemented. The patient's code status is full code, and disposition is pending.

   Assessment and Plan
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia s/p biopsy of new L lobe mass.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:  Extubated yesterday and has been stable off
   vent so far, still with high O2 requirement but weaning down. Will help
   his respiratory status by diuresis as CXR showing more fluid in lungs
   s/p extubation
   - run his I/Os negative today ( neg 1-2 L )
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#18 today, down
   to 10mg daily)
   - Talk to family regarding pathology results of squamous cell ca and
   goals of care/next steps
   # Delirium: Patient with delirium/anxiety when not sedated.
   - continue Haldol 3mg qpm and 1-2 mg PRN q 8 hrs during daytime
   - check EKG / QT  today
   -consider using depakote
   #HAP : Recent MRSA PNA and bacteremia. No recent fevers or
   leukocytosis.
   - continue Zosyn x 10 days total (day #8 today) and IV Vanco x 6 weeks
   - CIS
   - change Vanco to 1g q 24 hours
   .
   # L sided lung mass:  IP biopsy results now confirmed as squamous cell
   lung cancer.
   - consider family meeting with goals of care changes
   - staging with CT studies once more stable
   -heme/onc consult today  & possibly RAD/Onc involvement
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   - restarted on beta blocker and titrate up for now
   - restarted on plavix yesterday, continue plavix
   - continue  ASA 81mg
   - start ACE today or tomorrow as tolerated for afterload reduction
   #CHF:  recent EF 35%. Fluid overloaded on exam
   - consider starting ACE today or tomorrow, BP allowing
   -will diuresed to goal negative 1-2L today
   - keep MAPs >65
   # Hypotension:  Off pressors. Improved off propofol sedation
   - f/up micro/ culture data
   - monitor I/Os with goal even/slightly negative today, try to maintain
   UOP > 30cc/hr with close watch on CVPs ( goal >7) & MAPs ( >65)
   .
   # Atach/afib: Plan to continue on PO Amiodarone.  Overnight still had
   several brief runs of SVT but no need for any re-bolus of amiodarone as
   resolved  quickly. [**Month (only) 51**] have been due to volume changes and increased
   diuresis.
   -continue lopressor 5mg q 4hrs for control
   - continue PO amiodarone
   -cont telemetry

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy, and coronary artery disease (s/p CABG). The patient was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and bacteremia following a biopsy of a new left lobe mass.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C (98.2°F), heart rate of 84 bpm with a range of 80-106 bpm, blood pressure of 126/52 mmHg with a range of 76-131/44-80 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute with a range of 20-39 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on high-flow nasal cannula.

The patient is extubated and stable off the ventilator but still requires a high O2 requirement. He is being weaned down slowly as tolerated. The physical examination reveals bibasilar crackles and anterior rhonchi in the lungs, jugular venous pressure (JVP) of 8 cm, regular heart sounds with no murmurs, and no overt signs of distress.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 10.2 K/uL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 27.2 mg/dL, creatinine (Cr) of 1.6 mg/dL, and lactic acid of 0.9 mmol/L. The patient has an elevated potassium level of 5.

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer with right upper lobe lobectomy, and CAD (s/p CABG) admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in the setting of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia s/p biopsy of new left lobe mass. 

The patient has been extubated for more than 48 hours and has been stable off the vent so far, still with a high O2 requirement but weaning down. His respiratory status will be helped by diuresis as the CXR showing more fluid in the lungs s/p extubation. 

The patient is running his I/Os negative today and will be even to -500cc today. He will have DC lasix gtt. He will continue steroid taper and MDIs (PO prednisone day#18 today, down to 10mg daily) - keep at 10mg for now as the patient still has wheezing. 

The family will be talked to regarding the pathology results of squamous cell ca and goals of care/next steps. The patient's standing nebs will be made sure on. 

The patient has delirium/anxiety when not sedated. Reassess in the afternoon, check ABG. He will continue Haldol 3mg qpm and 1-2 mg PRN q8hrs during daytime. His EKG / QT today will be checked. He may consider using depakote.

He was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure due to MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia following a biopsy of a new left lobe mass. The patient was extubated yesterday and has been stable off the ventilator so far, still requiring high oxygen but weaning down. The assessment includes respiratory failure, delirium, healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP), left-sided lung mass, coronary artery disease (CAD) post CABG, congestive heart failure (CHF), hypotension, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib/VR), and a drop in hemoglobin concentration.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable as indicated by the need for high oxygen requirement. There is a risk of recurrent respiratory failure if weaning off the ventilator is unsuccessful.
2. Delirium: The patient continues to experience delirium/anxiety when not sedated. This can lead to agitation, confusion, and increased risk of falls or self-harm.
3. Healthcare-Associated Pneumonia (HAP): The patient has a recent history of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. There is a risk of recurrent or resistant infections if appropriate antibiotics are not administered.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of COPD, lung cancer (right upper lobe lobectomy), and CAD (post coronary artery bypass grafting). He was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure due to MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia following a biopsy of a new left lobe mass.

The patient has been extubated for over 48 hours and is stable off the ventilator, but still requires high oxygen supplementation. The plan is to continue weaning him off oxygen. A chest X-ray shows more fluid in the lungs post-extubation, so diuresis will be helpful in his respiratory status.

The patient's current issues include respiratory failure, delirium, hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), left-sided lung mass, CAD, congestive heart failure (CHF), hypotension, atrial fibrillation, and stress gastritis. 

Treatment plans include running his inputs and outputs negative, continuing steroid taper and MDIs, discussing pathology results and goals of care with the family, reassessing delirium, checking ABG, considering using depakote, and monitoring O2 saturations.

Medications include IV Vancomycin and Piperacillin-tazobactam, which will be discontinued today. Other medications include Heparin sodium (prophylaxis), Furosemide (Lasix), Haloperidol (Haldol), Metoprolol, and others as per the ICU care plan.

Laboratory results show leukocytosis, elevated creatinine, and other abnormalities, indicating possible kidney dysfunction and ongoing infection. 

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still dependent on high flow oxygen, which increases the risk of oxygen toxicity and impaired gas exchange. Close monitoring of respiratory status and gradual weaning off oxygen is crucial.

2. Delirium: The patient exhibits delirium and anxiety when not sedated. Reassessing the patient's mental status and adjusting medication dosages (particularly antipsychotics) is essential to prevent further complications like falls or worsening agitation.

3. Hospital-Acquired Pneumonia (HAP): The patient has a history of MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. Discontinuing unnecessary antibiotics and implementing strict infection control measures are important to prevent further infections.

4. Left-Sided Lung Mass: The patient has a confirmed squamous cell lung cancer. Staging with CT studies once more stable and discussing treatment options with the family is necessary to manage the cancer progression.

5. CAD, s/p CABG: The patient's coronary artery disease and recent CABG surgery put him at risk for cardiac complications. Monitoring the patient's cardiac status, restarting beta-blockers, and maintaining optimal blood pressure control are essential.

6. Congestive Heart Failure (CHF): The patient's recent ejection fraction of 35% indicates reduced cardiac function. Monitoring fluid balance, using diuretics, and

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and prior lung cancer requiring lobectomy. He was admitted with hypoxia due to MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. The patient now has a recurrent lung cancer diagnosis confirmed by recent biopsy of the left lobe mass. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient still has high O2 requirements despite being extubated over 48 hours ago. There is a concern for pulmonary overload, as indicated by worsening pulmonary edema on chest X-ray. Diuretics have been used aggressively, and the patient's I/Os are being monitored with a goal of negative 500cc to maintain a UOP of more than 30cc/hr.
2. Delirium: The patient exhibits delirium/anxiety when not sedated. Haloperidol has been prescribed for symptom management, and an EKG to check QT interval will be done today. Depakote may be considered for treatment.
3. Healthcare-associated pneumonia (HAP): The patient has recently had MRSA pneumonia and bacteremia. He has completed a 10-day course of Zosyn and is now continuing IV Vancomycin for six weeks.
4. Left-sided lung mass: The patient's recent biopsy confirms squamous cell lung cancer. The family has agreed to a DNR/D

The patient is a 65-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient's condition has been unstable, with fluctuations in vital signs and organ function. The patient's DNR/DNI status was updated, and palliative care was requested. Central line complications and replacement of the Dopamine pump occurred. The patient received multiple doses of antibiotics (Vancomycin and Piperacillin) and various ICU medications, including heparin sodium, furosemide, haloperidol, and metoprolol.

The patient's vital signs show hypotension with a blood pressure of 120/52 mmHg and low oxygen saturation (SpO2) at 89%. The patient is on high-flow nasal cannula for respiratory support. The patient's heart rhythm is paced, and there is no assessment of peripheral vascular pulses or neurologic status.

Lab results indicate an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 172 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin (Hgb) level at 8.7 g/dL, increased blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 113 mg/dL, and elevated creatinine (Cr) level of 1.9 mg/dL. Other lab values show abnormalities in electrolytes, liver enzymes, and kidney function.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including impaired aerobic capacity/endurance, impaired arousal, attention, and cognition, impaired

The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and previous SCLC who presented with MRSA bacteremia and pna. He was found to have recurrent left upper lobe lung cancer. The patient is currently in respiratory failure due to volume overload, COPD, and improving pneumonia. He is being treated with diuretics, antibiotics, and respiratory support.

The patient also has confusion, which is somewhat improved, and he is being given Haldol. He has newly diagnosed recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma and is being considered for staging evaluation if he improves. The patient is also experiencing atrial tachycardia and is being treated with amiodarone and lopressor.

Additionally, the patient has acute on chronic renal failure with mildly elevated creatinine levels. He is being monitored closely, and the rest of the plan is per resident note. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, and prophylactic measures for DVT, stress ulcers, and VAP.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a result of volume overload, COPD, and improving pneumonia. The main complication to watch out for is worsening respiratory status, leading to further deterioration in oxygenation and ventilation. Close monitoring of vital signs, particularly respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, and blood pressure, is essential. Frequent assessments of lung sounds and chest

Summary:
The patient is a 66-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and SCLC who presented with MRSA bacteremia and pneumonia. He was found to have recurrent left upper lobe lung cancer. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure due to volume overload and improving pneumonia, confusion, squamous cell carcinoma recurrence, atrial tachycardia, acute on chronic renal failure, and fecal occult blood. The patient has been diuresed well using lasix PRN, and his TBB goal is even slightly negative today. He is being continued on vancomycin for a total of 6 weeks, completing a 10-day Zosyn course. His respiratory sounds are clearer today, and he will continue with prednisone taper and standing nebs. The target SaO2 range is 88-92%. His confusion has somewhat improved, and he is now being given Haldol. The newly diagnosed recurrence of squamous cell carcinoma will be evaluated for staging if he improves from his current status. The atrial tachycardia will continue to be managed with amiodarone and lopressor. The patient's creatinine levels are stably mildly elevated, and he will continue to be monitored in the context of diuresis. He has started total parenteral nutrition (TF) via Dobhoff. The rest of the plan is per resident note.

   Assessment and Plan
   68 year-old male with COPD, h/o lung cancer with RUL lobectomy, & CAD (
   s/p CABG) who was admitted with hypotension and respiratory failure in
   setting of MRSA PNA and bacteremia and now has recurrent lung cancer
   diagnosis s/p recent biopsy of  left  lobe mass.
   .
   # Respiratory failure:
   Extubated >48hrs ago and has been stable off vent so far, still with
   significant O2 requirements but weaning down gradually. Yesturday
   patient had worse fluid overload on  CXR so he was diuresed more
   aggressively
   - run even today
   - lasix gtt only PRN , keeping UOP > 30cc/hr
   - Continue steroid taper and MDIs  ( PO prednisone
 day#19 today, down
   to 10mg daily)  - keep at 10mg for now as patient still with wheezing
   - continue  on standing nebs
   - wean FiO2 as tolerates , patient and family now decided do not want
   re-intubation if he decompensates to that point
   # Delirium
   Remains confused intermittently c/w delirium
   - continue Haldol 3mg qpm and 1-2 mg PRN q 8 hrs during daytime
   - check EKG / QT  today
   - keep O2 sats around 90-92%
   - wean steroids to off
   - reorient frequently, out of bed, enforce sleep/wake cycles
   .
   # NSCLC recurrence:  IP biopsy results now confirmed as squamous cell
   lung cancer.
   - family meeting done yesterday and goals of care changed to DNR/DNI
   - f/up palliative care team recs
   - will discuss with family whether further onc evaluation desired
   - social work involved
   # CAD,s/p CABG: No active issues
   - continue ASA, plavix  BB
   # CHF, systolic, chronic:  recent EF 35%. Patient more euvolemic today
   -  continue BB
   - I/o goal as above
   - consider ACEI when Cr trending back down
   .
   # Atach/afib:
   - continue amiodarone and metoprolol
   - monitoring on tele
   - follow K, Mg   PM labs  and replete aggressively
   .
   # Anemia
    Has been stable [**Month (only) 51**] be stress gastritis. Has not required transfusions
   since [**5-2**].
   -will trend HCTs [**Hospital1 7**], keep >25 given CAD history
   - active T/S
   - guaiac stools
   # CRI
   Cr slightly up today in setting of diuresis
   - continue to follow urine output, Cr

Summary: The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). He was admitted with hypoxia in the setting of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia and bacteremia, and now has a recurrence of lung cancer. The patient's current condition includes respiratory failure, delirium, NSCLC recurrence, chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 35%, atrial fibrillation, anemia, and chronic renal insufficiency. The patient's goals of care have been changed to do not resuscitate/do not intubate (DNR/DNI), and further oncologic evaluation is being considered. The patient is currently receiving various medications and treatments, including diuretics, steroids, noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, and antibiotics. He is also being monitored for electrolyte imbalances and renal function. The patient's nutritional support is being provided through a pulmonary diet.

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), coronary artery bypass graft (CABG), severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and prior non-small cell lung cancer (NSLC). He was admitted with hypoxia due to MRSA pneumonia with bacteremia and now has a recurrence of lung cancer. The patient received 40 IV lasix overnight and became agitated, but responded to Haldol. His EKG showed normal QT interval. The patient has no known drug allergies. He received Piperacillin and Vancomycin at different times. He is currently on heparin sodium for prophylaxis, as well as other ICU medications. The patient's review of systems remains unchanged except for new developments. Flow sheet data shows vital signs within normal range, with a slight variation in blood pressure. The patient is receiving high-flow nasal cannula for respiratory support and has a SpO2 of 96%. ABG results are pending. Physical examination findings are incomplete due to the patient's uncooperative behavior. Lab results indicate an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and abnormal electrolyte levels. Chest X-rays from different times show worsening lung infiltrates. Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous coronary artery bypass graft surgery, severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). He was admitted with hypoxia in the setting of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia and bacteremia. The patient now has a recurrence of lung cancer, confirmed by recent biopsy of the left lobe mass.

The patient's recent events include being extubated three days ago and being stable off the ventilator so far. He has been diuresed aggressively overnight for recent fluid overload. The plan is to continue steroid taper, wean oxygen as tolerated, and keep up with nebulizers and metered-dose inhalers. The patient and family have decided against re-intubation if he decompensates.

The patient remains very confused intermittently and has delirium with limited response to Haldol. The plan is to continue Haldol, add Seroquel at bedtime, monitor EKG and QT interval, maintain oxygen saturation above 90%, and wean steroids.

The patient has chronic systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 35%. He is on beta-blockers and will be uptitrated as tolerated.
